91: After the relentless surge in prices since 2021, the critical minerals market underwent another tumultuous year in 2023.
92: Prices for most materials experienced a significant decline, relinquishing most of the increases accumulated over the past two years.
93: Prices for battery metals saw particularly steep reductions due to an inventory overhang in the downstream sector, a slight easing in the pace of demand growth and an increase in overall supply.
94: While immediate concerns appear to have eased, the risks of market tightness and price volatility remain ever present as countries pursue decarbonisation goals.
95: Moreover, the geopolitical context is increasingly complex, highlighted by a series of trade restriction measures in 2023, including gallium, germanium, graphite and technologies related to rare earth elements.
96: Low material prices helped to put the costs of clean energy technologies back on a downward trajectory, but they present a challenge for efforts to diversify supply, given the financial difficulties that they pose for new and emerging producers.
97: The imperative to bolster the diversity and resilience of critical mineral supplies remains at the top of the policy agenda.
98: In line with new mandates approved by the 2024 Ministerial meeting, the IEA has been working together with countries and industry to address these emerging challenges and ensure reliable and sustainable supplies of critical minerals.
99: On 28 September 2023, the IEA hosted the first ever Critical Minerals and Clean Energy Summit at the IEA headquarters in Paris.
100: Almost 50 countries, including key producing and consuming nations around the world, came together with around 40 business leaders, investors, heads of international organisations and civil society organisations to share their experiences and discuss effective courses of action to ensure rapid and secure energy transitions.
101: Chief among various desired actions was the need for robust market monitoring and outlooks that can help bring a clear understanding of today’s market situation and anticipate potential risks in the medium to long term.
102: Earlier in 2023, the Group of Seven  ministers asked the IEA to play a strengthened role in safeguarding minerals security in its G7 Five Point Plan, through producing medium and long term outlooks for critical minerals and introducing the IEA Voluntary Critical Minerals Security Programme.
103: This report, following the inaugural Critical Minerals Market Review 2023, responds to these growing needs for enhanced market transparency by reviewing latest market movements, examining the prospects for future mineral demand and supply, and assessing potential risks along the supply chain of key commodities.

105: The Announced Pledges Scenario  assumes that governments will meet, in full and on time, all of the climaterelated commitments that they have announced, including longer term net zero emissions targets and pledges in nationally determined contributions .
106: The APS is associated with a temperature rise of 1,7 °C in 2100 .

108: Global clean energy deployment scaled new heights in 2023, with annual additions of solar PV growing 85% and wind turbines growing 60%.
109: The growth in clean energy deployment, however, remains concentrated in advanced economies and the People’s Republic of China , with most developing economies lagging behind.
110: Global solar PV capacity additions for electricity generation broke a new record, reaching 420 GW in 2023.
111: Solar PV alone accounted for three quarters of renewable capacity additions worldwide.
112: China alone accounted for 62% of the increase in global solar PV capacity.
113: Despite the phase out of central government subsidies, the country commissioned as much solar PV in 2023 as the entire world did in 2022.
114: In the European Union , annual solar PV additions rose by a quarter and reached a record level 52 GW in 2023.
115: Following the Russian Federation’s  invasion of Ukraine, the EU member states improved the policy environment to accelerate renewables deployment, in part to help bring down natural gas consumption.
116: This has led annual solar PV additions to double since 2021.
117: In the United States , solar PV capacity additions increased 50% year on year following the easing of supply chain issues that slowed deployment in 2022.
118: Federal tax incentives and state level support have continued to drive both utility scale and rooftop solar PV applications.
119: India added only 12 GW of solar PV in 2023, one third lower than in 2022.
120: Nevertheless, in 2023 the government unveiled an objective to conduct annual auctions for 50 GW of renewable energy capacity that promises to accelerate deployment significantly.
121: Global wind capacity additions jumped by 60% in 2023 to break the record seen in 2020.
122: Onshore wind projects accounted for over 85% of global wind deployment in 2023.
123: China accounted for more than 60% of global wind expansion as the country almost doubled its additions compared with 2022.
124: In the European Union, wind additions increased by less than 10% in 2023, with onshore wind deployment slowing down.
125: Developers have been facing multiple challenges, including rising equipment costs, inflation, and supply chain constraints, which have made them less eager to participate in competitive auctions.
126: Most countries in Europe have introduced policies to address the challenges posed by slow and complex permitting procedures for wind projects.
127: However, the impact of these policies will take time to be visible in deployment trends.
128: In the United States, wind additions declined by more than a quarter in 2023.
129: This was mainly due to prior uncertainty over the future of tax credits, prior to the adoption of the Inflation Reduction Act .
130: Wind capacity additions are expected to increase significantly in the coming years thanks to the policy visibility provided by the IRA.
131: In India, a larger number of projects awarded in previous years led annual deployment to increase by almost 50% in 2023.
132: Offshore wind growth has recovered from a major drop seen in annual additions in 2022.
133: However, the offshore industry outside of China is facing challenges with investment costs today more than 20% higher than a few years ago.
134: In 2023, developers cancelled or postponed 15 GW of offshore wind projects in the United States and the United Kingdom because pricing for previously awarded capacity no longer reflected prevailing project development costs.
135: Overall, the world is poised for a signficant acceleration in renewable capacity in the coming years driven by supportive policies in more than 130 countries.
136: Renewables are expected to surpass coal to become the largest source of electricity generation by the mid 2020s.
137: Substantial demand for materials such as copper, silicon and rare earth elements will be required to support the rapid deployment of renewable generation capacity.
138: However, challenges such as high interest rates and low profitability persist.
139: Policymakers need to address issues related to permitting and grid expansion to achieve the target of tripling global renewable capacity by 2030 that was agreed at the 28th Conference of the Parties .
140: The growing markets for eletrolysers could push up demand for nickel, platinum group metals, zirconium and other minerals depending on the specific technology deployed.
141: In 2023, global installed capacity of electrolysers for hydrogen production reached 1,3 GW, underpinned by a surge in annual additions to 600 MW.
142: However, this is still far from the annual multi gigawatt additions required to keep global climate goals within reach.
143: From less than 10% of global installed capacity in 2020, China has emerged as the leading region since 2021, reaching an installed capacity of more than 650 MW by the end of 2023.
144: China now represents close to half of the global installed capacity.
145: This transformation has been fuelled by the scaling up of project sizes by Chinese developers, with several projects now exceeding 100 MW in capacity.
146: Consequently, China now hosts six of the world's largest operational electrolysis projects.
147: The European Union accounted for around a third of global installed capacity in 2020, but has now ceded its leading position, with additions of around 70 MW in 2023.
148: The United States emerged as the third largest market, with additions exceeding 30 MW.
149: Demand uncertainty and lack of regulatory clarity, coupled with recent challenges such as inflation and slow implementation of support mechanisms are hindering faster adoption of electrolysers in other regions.
150: Electric car sales neared 14 million in 2023, a 35% year on year increase, and more than six times higher than five years earlier in 2018.
151: Electric cars accounted for 18% of all car sales in 2023 up from 14% in 2022 and only 2% five years earlier, and nearly 95% of all sales were in China, Europe and the United States.
152: These trends demonstrate robust growth in electric car markets as they become more mature, even if the growth in global electric car sales slowed somewhat compared with the 60% seen in 2022.
153: China is the world's largest electric car market with 8,1 million electric car sales and 60% of the global total in 2023, a share that has been increasing, up from 50% five years earlier in 2018.
154: In 2023 more than one in three new car registrations in China was electric.
155: The growth rate of electric car sales in China more than halved in 2023 to 35% from 80% in 2022.
156: One of the critical reasons for this is that 2023 was the first year that the government provided no purchase subsidies for electric cars, with their phase out in 2022.
157: Therefore, a slowdown of electric car sales was expected.
158: This is also coupled with relatively weak consumer sentiment.
159: As the Chinese market matures, the industry is entering a phase of price competition and consolidation.
160: To mitigate lower domestic demand, China exported 1,2 million electric vehicles  in 2023, an 80% increase from the previous year, with primary export markets being Europe and the Asia Pacific region including Thailand and Australia.
161: In April, China removed down payment requirements for new car loans in an effort to stimulate consumer demand.
162: In the first quarter of 2024 the year on year electric car sales growth rate in China increased to 36% compared with 27% in the same period last year.
163: It is estimated that around 45% of all cars sold in China in 2024 could be electric.
164: Europe is the second largest electric car market with almost 25% of global sales in 2023, reaching 3,2 million electric car sales.
165: This year more than one in five cars sold in Europe was electric.
166: Unlike China, Europe did not experience a slowdown as the growth rate of electric car sales slightly accelerated in 2023 to 20%, up from 15% in 2022.
167: However, sales trends differed by country.
168: In Germany the electric car sales share fell from 30% in 2022 to 25% in 2023 due to the sudden end of all EV subsidies in 2023, which were originally intended to apply until the end of 2024.
169: Nevertheless, in the rest of Europe electric car sales shares increased, with the Netherlands reaching 30%, the United Kingdom and France 25%, and Sweden 60%.
170: In the United States electric car sales grew to 1,4 million in 2023, increasing by 40% compared with 2022, the fastest growth rate of the three largest regions, though the sales share of electric cars reached only 10%.
171: The United States experienced a slight slowdown compared with the 55% rise in 2022, but growth in sales remained strong, with the IRA having supported sales despite some concerns about domestic component requirements hindering deployment.
172: The revision of eligibility criteria for IRA tax credits in 2023 meant several popular vehicles were covered, and the Tesla Model Y increased its sales by 50% year on year.
173: In 2024 new guidance significantly reduced the number of eligible vehicles for tax credits.
174: In the rest of the world, total electric car sales grew by 70% and sales almost reached 1 million electric cars.
175: India experienced 70% year on year growth, with sales of 80 000 vehicles, compared with just 10% growth for total car sales.
176: In Thailand electric car sales increased more than fourfold, reaching 90 000 vehicles and a 10% market share, a particularly impressive achievement given that total car sales decreased from 2022 to 2023.
177: Subsidies in both regions have facilitated demand growth though India is anticipated to reduce subsidy levels in 2024.
178: In both China and the United States, sales of plug in hybrid electric vehicles  grew significantly faster than battery electric vehicles  .
179: As a result, the share of PHEVs in EV sales reached 33% in China, up from 25% in 2022, and 20% in the United States.
180: Concerns about driving range and lack of sufficient charging infrastructure for BEVs appear to be the driving force.
181: In China, this surge in PHEV demand suggest that the growing middle class appear to be more concerned about range going forward, marking a break from the past where relatively low range BEVs were popular.
182: The average battery size for PHEVs in China is around 50% higher than in Europe.
183: A recent trend in China has been towards extended range EVs , which have an electric powertrain but also have a combustion engine able to recharge the battery.
184: EREVs have a battery around twice the size of a typical PHEV, enabling real world electric range of around 150 km, more than double that of conventional PHEVs.
185: In 2023 EREVs accounted for a quarter of Chinese PHEV sales, a 10% increase from 2022, although EREVs have a negligible sale share outside of China.
186: Europe, however, saw significantly higher growth in BEV sales with over 30% growth year on year compared with a small drop in PHEV sales in 2023.
187: Although growth rates in EV sales are slowing, early signs from 2024 indicated that sales remain generally strong.
188: As the market matures and subsidies are phased out, growth rates may decrease somewhat.
189: However, robust growth in EV sales is still expected to continue in the near and long term, supported by ongoing policy momentum, major increases in manufacturing capacity, cost declines and expanded adoption in developing economies.
190: In 2023, global battery demand from EVs and storage reached 865 GWh in 2023, a 45% year on year increase.
191: This was primarily driven by sales of electric cars, which were responsible for 85% of global demand.
192: The annual growth rate for battery demand from electric cars, buses and trucks slowed in 2023 to 40%, compared with 75% in 2022, in line with broader sales trends, although annual demand growth from two or three wheelers increased.
193: Battery storage demand experienced the most impressive rise, more than doubling from the 2022 level, bringing its share in total EV and storage demand up to 10%.
194: Given that growth rates for battery storage had almost doubled in 2021, this represents a remarkable surge in utility scale and behind the metre storage deployment.
195: China was the largest source of battery demand in 2023 with 55% of the global total, followed by Europe with around a quarter and the United States with 15%, in each case dominated by EV sales.
196: Battery demand in China grew by over 40% in 2023 this was half the rate seen in 2023 despite a threefold rise in demand for storage deployment.
197: Battery demand in Europe and the United States both grew by 45%, a higher rate than for electric car sales due to a combination of larger vehicle and battery sizes and higher rates of storage deployment.
198: Alongside sales, the rise in battery sizes for EVs is a critical driver of growth in demand for batteries and for critical minerals.
199: In most regions the average battery size for passenger BEVs has been increasing year on year, with the global average increasing more than 60% since 2017.
200: The trend towards an increasing share of sport utility vehicles  found in conventional car markets
201: is being replicated in the EV market.
202: Automakers are focusing on larger vehicles, which are typically more profitable, and consumers appear to have a strong appetite for larger vehicles and ranges, even if they are often beyond their requirements.
203: All regions follow the same overall trend for increased battery sizes, but there are significant regional variations in absolute values.
204: The average battery size in the United States is 30% larger than the global average, Europe is 10% larger while China is 10% smaller.
205: This mirrors size trends in conventional vehicle sectors, and also shows the greater preference from consumers in the United States and Europe for higher range EVs.
206: Battery pack price trends In 2023 average battery pack prices dropped 14% to a record low of USD 139/kWh.
207: This was the largest price decrease since 2018, driven primarily by the fall in critical minerals prices, in combination with a surge in battery production capacity and slightly weaker demand than expected.
208: This reinstates the trend of declining battery prices that was temporarily reversed in 2022 due to the exceptionally high prices of battery critical minerals.
209: Cells now account for 80% of the total pack price, an increasing ratio partly due to the cell to pack  design innovation reducing dead weight in the pack and pack costs.
210: With decreasing manufacturing costs from economies of scale and innovation, critical minerals have been a growing share of the battery pack cost, leaving the battery pack price more susceptible to mineral price volatility.
211: This was seen clearly in 2022 when cathode raw materials peaked at 30% of the total pack price before falling back to to 25% in 2023.
213: One of the most remarkable developments in the global battery sector in the last five years has been the resurgence of the lithium iron phosphate  cathode chemistry.
214: With a lower energy density but more stable and lower cost chemistry compared to the nickel based chemistries, LFP was being phased out in favour of the significantly higher energy density nickel based cathode chemistries.
215: However, there has been a remarkable reversal of fortune since 2019.
216: The fact that LFP contains no nickel or cobalt became an important asset that helped reduced exposure to high commodity prices.
217: In addition, the emergence of CTP technology eliminated dead weight in the battery pack and enhanced the energy density of LFP.
218: CTP was pioneered by BYD with the Blade battery.
219: LFP has now become a major chemistry in 2023 with around 40% of electric car battery sales by capacity.
220: Due to favourable patent agreements China had been the only country producing LFP batteries after 2010.
221: However, the patents expired in 2022, which kick started production plans outside China.
222: Nevertheless, there are still major regional differences, less than 10% of total EV sales by capacity in the United States and Europe are LFP while two thirds are LFP in China.
223: Another major recent innovation was the first fast charging LFP battery, Shenxing developed by CATL, capable of delivering 400km of range from a ten minute charge.
224: This is achieved through a new electrolyte and graded anode porosities among other innovations.
225: The novel fast charging LFP battery will be utilised in EV vehicles this year, significantly increasing the attractiveness of LFP chemistries.
226: The other significant recent LFP innovation is the development and commercialisation of lithium manganese iron phosphate , the upgraded version of LFP including manganese which increases its energy density.
227: With CATL’s M3P battery confirmed for use in six Chinese EV models and undergoing validation by Tesla for its Chinese Model 3, it is anticipated that LMFP will continue to take market share from nickel based chemistries due to its increased range.
228: In terms of the anode, silicon doped graphite anodes are increasing in market share with almost a third of electric car anode capacity market share.
229: Higher fractions of silicon are also being used with 10% silicon graphite anodes doubling in market share in 2023 to 12%.
230: Silicon doping increases the energy density of the graphite anode, and increased doping and higher quantities of silicon are expected in the near future.
231: Looking beyond lithium ion chemistries, sodium ion  batteries have experenced a surge of development in recent years, especially while lithium prices were high.
232: As the name suggests, this chemistry contains no lithium and also requires less critical minerals than lithium ion batteries.
233: Leading batterymakers including CATL, Northvolt and many others announced their sodium ion cells.
234: However, the fall in lithium prices has diminished the advantage of sodium ion chemistries and major ramping up plans have stalled or been delayed.
235: The progress of sodium ion batteries hinges on their price advantage over lithium ion, with major influence of the lithium price.
236: All solid state batteries  are the anticipated step change technology for battery energy density and safety.
237: There has been widespread industrial research and development in recent years, yet major technical challenges remain such as the typically high pressures required to ensure good electrode contact or relying on difficult to scale, expensive production processes.
238: Progress has been made utilising hybrid solid liquid electrolyte batteries, for instance from CATL and Quantumscape however, the use of an organic liquid electrolyte diminishes any safety advantage and may even have higher risks than conventional lithium ion batteries due to the use of lithium metal.
239: Progress is also being made with ASSBs, with Samsung, an industry leader in solid state, recently announcing plans for mass production in 2027.
240: CATL also expects to produce small scale production in the same year.
241: Though ASSBs hold potential in the future, they are not expected to have significant impact until after 2030.
242: One of the most critical considerations in the global battery outlook is the strength of manufacturing capacity in China.
243: China dominates the downstream battery supply chain, including processing of the battery minerals, cathode and anode material production, and battery cell and EV production.
244: China holds 85% of battery cell production capacity and 90% of cathode and 98% of anode material production capacity globally.
245: Over half of global processing for lithium and cobalt occurs in China.
246: The country dominates the entire graphite anode supply chain end to end.
247: China also produces two thirds of the world's EVs.
248: In almost all stages of the midstream and downstream supply chain, China has increased its market share since 2021.
249: China has been building battery plants and cathode and anode production capacity at a speed that exceeds projected demand.
250: In 2023 China’s maximum cell production capacity was more than double the amount needed to meet the country’s battery cell demand.
251: For cathode active materials, the manufacturing capacity anticipated in 2030 is about two times greater than the projected battery cell manufacturing capacity in the same year.
252: In the case of anode active materials, this ratio increases to five times greater, raising doubts about whether all cathode and anode material manufacturers will be able to remain competitive in the face of such a surplus.
253: There are several reasons for China’s strong manufacturing position.
254: The fruits of China’s industrial strategy have been seen already in many sectors including solar, aluminium and steel.
255: Years of government support, alongside a large and growing domestic market, have meant that the EV and battery industries in China have thrived and gained global market share.
256: This has now set the stage for considerable price competition and consolidation.
257: High technology manufacturing is now a pivotal element of China’s strategy for growth.
258: Ample manufacturing capacity across the battery supply chain is a double edged sword.

524: On the other hand, jurisdictions on the supply side have focused on ensuring economic benefits from their own resources.

588: Critical mineral supply chains cannot be truly secure, reliable and resilient unless they are also sustainable and responsible.
589: The mining industry does not have the best track record managing ESG impacts, but many players are aiming to change that.
590: Our assessment of company progress across various ESG dimensions , based on the public sustainability reports and commitments published by 25 major companies that have a strong presence in critical minerals supply chains , shows progress in reporting and growing commitments.
591: All of these companies report efforts to improve their ESG performance, but goals vary starkly.
592: About 20 have pledged to achieve net zero emissions by or before 2050, with the remaining yet to establish a firm long term emissions target.
593: Most net zero targets apply only to emissions from direct operations  or purchased energy and heat , leaving out other emissions from the industry’s value chains .
594: Around five companies have established targets to reduce absolute emissions by 35% or more by 2030 or earlier.
595: Many companies refer to a reduction in emissions intensities to 2030 or have established reduction targets only for 2035.
596: Several industry players have also committed to other ESG goals, such as causing no net loss of biodiversity or limiting the amount of freshwater used in mining.
597: These commitments are being followed by better reporting of ESG practices.
598: Our assessment revealed an increase in the availability of data for the latest years, indicating the industry is putting more effort into tracking its performance.
599: The number of companies reporting investment in communities, female share of workers and water discharge increased by 40% or more during this period.
600: All players now report GHG emissions and nearly 90% report share of female workers, injury rates and community investment.
601: Nevertheless, an industry wide assessment of progress on ESG still faces many challenges.
602: Only around ten companies published data on land area disturbed and rehabilitated, and less than five reported on involuntary resettlement.
603: Few operators detail risks related to their supply chains, such as potential child labour, or provide clear information on contract disclosure.
604: ESG reporting varies substantially in both consistency and breadth.
605: Most companies aggregate their reported data in some form or another, often at the company level, making it difficult to compare performance for specific minerals or regions.
606: Less than five companies disclosed site level data consistently in their reports positive examples include Aracdium Lithium, Codelco, and First Quantum.
607: Units and scope of reporting also vary, sometimes even within the same report .
608: The sustainable and responsible supply of critical minerals depends on a myriad of interrelated practices, from water stewardship to emissions management, engaging with communities and ensuring safe labour standards, a fair share of benefits, protecting biodiversity, reducing waste, and much more.
609: The industry is making progress on several of these fronts.
610: From 2019 to 2022, reported injury rates decreased by nearly 30%, investments in communities surged from USD 0,3 billion to USD 1 billion, and the average share of female workers went from just over 15% to 20%.
611: Data are more sparse for other indicators, but available information suggests improvements in the amount of waste being recovered through reprocessing and reuse and the share of water that is being recycled or re used in industry facilities.
612: These positive trends do not hold for all companies, but reflect widespread industry efforts.
613: On the other hand, there are many areas where progress has been limited and some even show negative trends.
614: The amount of waste generated per unit of mineral produced increased by over 20% from 2019 to 2022, potentially due to the development of lower grade resources.
615: Reported water consumption increased by around 25% during this period even in the face of high supply risks related to droughts for copper and other minerals.
616: Similarly, indicators related to land rehabilitation, effluent discharge and GHG emissions did not exhibit visible improvements despite growing ESG commitments.
617: Voluntary sustainability standards can help actors improve performance and earn ESG credentials.
618: These include the ICMM‘s Mining Principles and performance expectations, the Initiative for Responsible Mining Assurance‘s Standard for Responsible Mining, Canada’s Towards Sustainable Mining, the Responsible Minerals Initiative and the Copper Mark’s Risk Readiness Assessment Criteria Guide.
619: While these standards can all lead to increased transparency and sustainability performance, there are major differences between the overall stringency of requirements, the scope of their application, the approach to compliance and reporting, uptake, and in oversight and assurance systems.
620: Greater transparency, due diligence, harmonised approaches to credibility and appropriate incentives are needed to untap their full potential.
621: Material traceability services are also on the rise.
622: This involves working with suppliers to track sources and related impacts up to the point of incorporation into an end product.
623: It can allow an assessment of risks and ESG performance along the supply chain, contributing to increased mineral security.
624: Policymakers and companies, however, should be aware of the limitations of end to end product traceability.
625: Due to the nature of both aggregation and blending in mineral supply chains, particularly at the smelting and refinery stage, traceability is not always possible or practical.
626: Traceability mechanisms can be paired with a risk mitigation approach for better ESG due diligence.
627: The world is on a journey towards achieving net zero emissions, and has declared its ambition to limit global warming to 1,5 °C, which would mean completing this journey already by 2050.
628: Whichever pathway this journey eventually takes, it will require a massive expansion of clean energy technology deployment, along with reliable supplies of critical minerals.
629: While short term market dynamics are crucial, medium to long term perspectives on critical minerals demand and supply are equally important to ensure that clean energy transitions are not hindered by supply chain bottlenecks.
630: There are numerous questions that need to be addressed.
631: How fast might demand for critical minerals grow under different assumptions about the strength of climate action?
632: Can we ensure sufficient volumes of critical minerals to support the acceleration of energy transitions?
633: What are the key risk areas that policymakers need to monitor, and how do prospects vary by mineral?
634: Where are today's project developments leading us in 2030 and beyond, in terms of diversified supplies?
635: What role do environmental, social, and governance  considerations play in shaping future market developments?
636: This chapter addresses these crucial questions by providing a comprehensive outlook for demand and supply for key energy transition minerals, namely copper, lithium, nickel, cobalt, graphite and rare earth elements.
637: Additionally, we also briefly discuss key issues around aluminium, manganese, silicon, phosphate and platinum group metals .
638: Demand projections encompass both clean energy applications and other uses, focusing on the three IEA scenarios , the Stated Policies Scenario , the Announced Pledges Scenario  and the Net Zero Emissions by 2050  Scenario , with a particular focus on the latter two climate driven scenarios in which national and/or global climate goals are achieved .

640: Supply projections are based on a detailed review of all announced projects.
641: We have constructed two supply scenarios , a base case and a high production case.
642: The base case includes production from existing assets and those under construction, along with projects that have a high chance of moving ahead as they have obtained all necessary permits, secured financing, and/or established offtake contracts.
643: The high production case additionally considers projects at a reasonably advanced stage of development, seeking financing and/or permits.
644: In many instances, these projects are in the process of conducting feasibility studies, and in some cases these assessments are already complete.
645: Neither case considers projects that are in very early stages of development, or includes theoretical projects for which resources might be adequate but which have not been proposed.
646: For these reasons, our focus on the supply side is on the period to 2040.
647: Based on these two supply scenarios, we assess how today's geographical concentration evolves over time, for both mining and refining, and how expected supply compares with primary supply requirements in climate driven scenarios .
648: In some cases, we highlight potential gaps between expected supplies and material requirements in climate driven scenarios.
649: We do not attempt to close these gaps by introducing additional projects beyond those already underway or being considered.
650: Climate driven scenarios, the NZE Scenario in particular, reflect many demand side measures such as higher recycling rates, some behavioural changes , but we recognise that there is a possibility of additional demand side measures or technological innovation which could contribute to reducing demand further.
651: The aim of the exercise is to provide a framework for assessing progress towards achieving global energy security and climate goals and risks that may arise along the way.
652: There remain considerable uncertainties over how market balances evolve in practice.
653: On the demand side, it should be noted that the world is not yet on track for the outcomes in the APS or the NZE Scenario doing so will require significant additional efforts by policymakers and industries alike.
654: Where gaps are identified between future demand and supply, these may potentially be closed by developing additional projects, scaling up recycling further, and promoting a range of material efficiency measures beyond what are already assumed.
655: The results should not be interpreted to mean that energy transition goals are unattainable due to material constraints.
656: This chapter starts a brief review of projected mineral demand in the clean energy sector and presents overall findings of the detailed outlook for key energy transition minerals.
657: Each mineral section then presents demand and supply projection results and discusses key issues underpinning long term market developments.

660: The growth of power generation capacity from low emissions sources accelerates in all three scenarios.
661: Renewables account for the majority of capacity additions in every region over the outlook period.
662: By far, wind and solar PV are the largest contributors to this development, and total installed solar PV capacity in particular far outstrips that of any other source in all scenarios.
663: By 2026, solar PV becomes the largest contributor to installed electrical capacity in the STEPS, followed by wind.
664: This growth trajectory would see global renewable capacity increase to 2,5 times its current level by 2030, a major expansion but one that falls short of the tripling goal agreed at COP28.
665: Government actions to facilitate grid connections, and resolve permitting, policy and financing issues, are needed to accelerate growth.
666: In the APS, low emissions power sources account for almost 80% of total power capacity additions in 2030, with solar PV making up 55% and wind 20%.
667: Annual solar PV and wind capacity additions grow by two times to 2050 in the APS and by over two and a half times in the NZE Scenario.
668: The acceleration of renewable energy deployment calls for modernising distribution grids and establishing new transmission corridors to connect renewable resources that are far from demand centres such as cities and industrial areas.
669: Around 3 000 GW of renewable power projects are waiting in grid connection queues , equivalent to five times the amount of solar PV and wind capacity added in 2022.
670: Due to aged infrastructure and a high share of variable renewables in the system across the globe, reaching national goals also means adding or refurbishing a total of over 80 million km of grids by 2040, the equivalent of the entire existing global grid.
671: This would underpin significant growth of copper and aluminium demand for cables.
672: Grid investment growth in the past decade has occurred mainly in the People’s Republic of China  and advanced economies.
673: China alone accounted for over one third of the world’s transmission grid expansion in the past decade, connecting, among other places, the eastern load centres to the renewable energy rich provinces.
674: With ongoing policy support, improving economics, and an expanding number of models available, global EV sales
675: are set to grow strongly, more than tripling by 2030 in the STEPS and APS to almost 45 million and 50 million vehicles, respectively, and increasing more than fivefold to 70 million in the NZE Scenario.
676: This is primarily driven by the sales of electric cars, where a global sales share of 18% in 2023 increases to 45% in the STEPS and almost 50% in the APS by 2030, while reaching two thirds of all sales in the NZE Scenario.
677: This rapid sales growth continues to accelerate to 2050 with sales growing more than fivefold in the STEPS and over sevenfold in the APS.
678: Sales grow almost eightfold in the NZE Scenario by 2050 reaching 110 million vehicles.
679: The share of electric cars in total car sales continues to surge, reaching 60% in the STEPS, over three quarters in the APS and over 95% in the NZE Scenario by 2050.
680: This exceptional growth in EV sales drives a dramatic growth in battery demand.
681: From almost 1 TWh in 2023, demand more than quadruples by 2030 in the STEPS to 3,8 TWh and reaches 4,4 TWh in the APS, while increasing sevenfold to 6 TWh by 2030 in the NZE Scenario.
682: The growth rates in battery demand outpace growth in EV sales due to additional demand growth of battery storage, which surpasses the rates of demand growth for light duty vehicles in both the STEPS and APS by 2030 and by 2050.
683: There is also significant growth in battery demand for electric trucks, which increases eighteen fold in the STEPS and twenty three fold in the APS by 2030.
684: In the NZE Scenario, EV battery demand grows sevenfold.
685: By 2050 global battery demand reaches 9 TWh in the STEPS and 12 TWh in the APS, growing tenfold and fourteen fold from 2023 demand, respectively.
686: In the APS, demand from electric trucks becomes larger than global storage demand in 2050.
687: In the NZE Scenario demand reaches 13 TWh, a fifteen fold increase.
688: In 2023 battery production capacity  is two and half times battery demand.

693: When preliminary announcements are included, production capacity exceeds APS demand by 80% and is 40% greater than demand in the NZE Scenario.
694: Of all new committed capacity additions from 2023, 55% are in China by 2030.
695: These projections imply intense price competition among producers, with significant implications for global battery supply chains.
696: In terms of electric car cathode chemistries, lithium iron phosphate  and lithium manganese iron phosphate
697: are set to become the leading chemistries by share from 2035.
698: The LFP variant LMFP looks likely to be increasingly utilised, taking share from LFP and also from the high nickel chemistries due to its higher energy density than conventional LFP.
699: Low nickel high cobalt chemistries such as the nickel manganese cobalt  333 are assumed to be phased out by 2030, with the trend of reducing cobalt content in favour of higher nickel contents continuing.
700: Manganese rich chemistries including lithium manganese rich NMC  and lithium nickel manganese oxide
702: start to take increasing shares of the high nickel and LFP market.
703: LNMO are anticipated to take a small share of the mid range market, being higher energy density than LFP but not near the levels of the high nickel chemistries.

706: However, their share of the EV market is expected to decrease from 55% in 2023 to around 40% in 2040, as manganese rich chemistries and LFP/LMFP continue to displace them.
707: This is a remarkable change from 2020 when high nickel chemistries dominated the EV battery market.
708: Finally, sodium ion batteries are anticipated to play an increasingly significant role after 2030, reaching a global market share of almost 10% in 2040, displacing some LFP in the low range EV market, particularly if lithium prices rise and if there are phosphorous supply issues for LFP.
709: Our analysis suggest that LFP remains the preferred solution for the battery storage market, with a growing longer term role for sodium ion.
710: Looking at anodes, current trends indicate a growing share of silicon doped graphite anodes and a shift towards higher silicon contents.
711: This trend continues to displace conventional graphite anodes, eventually reaching high silicon contents above 50% and ultimately silicon anodes for long range premium markets.
712: Lithium metal anodes are anticipated to eventually play a greater role after 2035 with ASSBs, hybrid liquid solid state batteries and advanced liquid electrolytes, starting with the most premium long range vehicles.
713: However, the speed of deployment is highly uncertain and dependent on considerable technical and scaling challenges to be solved.
714: Finally, with the increasing adoption of sodium ion batteries, hard carbon, anode material for sodium ion batteries takes a greater share of the electric car anode market.
715: The accelerating pace of energy transitions is set to significantly boost mineral demand across all the three scenarios.
716: In the STEPS, demand doubles to 2030 with continued growth thereafter.
717: In the APS, demand more than doubles by 2030 and triples by 2050.
718: In the NZE Scenario, the swifter adoption of clean energy technologies implies an even more pronounced surge in demand for critical minerals, nearly tripling by 2030 and growing to over 3,5 times the current levels by 2050, reaching nearly 40 Mt.
719: Our latest mineral demand projections have been updated from those in the Critical Minerals Market Review 2023, reflecting several new technological and policy developments: • Projected demand in the STEPS has been revised upwards due to faster clean energy deployments, notably in solar PV installations and EV sales, driven by strengthened policy measures and improved economics for these technologies.
720: • Although they face some short term headwinds, EV sales have also been revised slightly upwards in the long term, driven by improving economics and policy efforts in major markets.
721: • LFP shares have increased considerably over the last years, and its rapidly growing global share has been reflected in the updated chemistry projections.
722: Manganese based chemistries also take a larger share in the future in the revised assumptions.
723: Alongside assessments of other emerging technologies such as sodium ion batteries, solid state batteries and silicon based anodes, near and long term battery chemistry assumptions have been adjusted, affecting demand projections for nickel, cobalt, manganese, and other materials.
724: The projected deployment of battery storage has been revised upward to account for the rapid pace of deployment in recent years and the increasing need for power system flexibility, resulting in increased demand for battery metals, lithium in particular.
725: Material intensity assumptions have been updated based on the latest literature review and industry consultations.
726: Graphite material requirements have been revised upwards in all scenarios, reflecting a more detailed representation of the amount of silicon required in anodes.
727: Each factor influences projected mineral requirements differently, resulting in slightly higher aggregated mineral demand across all three scenarios by 2050 compared with the previous outlook, with the STEPS seeing the largest overall upwards revision.
728: Demand for each mineral is affected in different ways from these revisions and updates.
729: Nickel sees the largest downwards revisions in both the APS and the NZE Scenario, largely due to the increased prominence of LFP, whereas graphite sees large upwards revisions in all scenarios.
730: However, despite these adjustments in projected mineral demand, demand in climate driven scenarios remains multiple times higher than current levels, underscoring the pivotal role of clean energy technologies in propelling total mineral demand growth.
731: From copper to lithium and to cobalt, clean energy technologies emerge as the predominant consuming segment, significantly elevating their share in total demand compared with present levels.
732: It is important to note that demand projections are subject to large variations, influenced not only by broader policy considerations  but also by technology costs and innovations, as well as behavioural factors.
733: To address this complexity, the IEA has developed more than ten alternative cases to assess the impacts of different consumer preferences and technology advancements on future mineral requirements.
734: The findings of these cases are available through the updated IEA Critical Minerals Data Explorer, an accompanying online data tool designed to allows users to easily access and navigate the projection results .
735: Demand for key energy transition minerals is set to expand significantly across all scenarios, mainly driven by the burgeoning requirements in the clean energy sector.
736: In the STEPS, demand for lithium grows fivefold between today and 2040, while demand for graphite almost doubles over the same period.
737: Demand for nickel, cobalt and rare earth elements also shows robust growth, increasing by 65 80% by 2040.
738: If the world gets on track to limit global warming to 1,5 °C, as modelled in the NZE Scenario, demand for copper rises by 50% by 2040.
739: In this scenario, demand for nickel, cobalt and rare earth elements doubles over the next two decades, and graphite demand increases by almost four times to 2040, propelled by the substantial increase in battery deployment for EVs and grid storage.
740: Of all the minerals, lithium stands out in this scenario with nearly ninefold growth by 2040, highlighting its crucial role in batteries.
741: Across all materials, the share of clean energy technologies in total demand rises significantly.
742: In most cases, the clean energy sector emerges as the largest consumer of these minerals.
743: In the NZE Scenario, EVs and battery storage are projected to account for over 90% of total lithium demand by 2030.
744: Moreover, batteries are poised to surpass stainless steel as the leading consumer sector for nickel.
745: As demand expands, the market value of these minerals experiences substantial growth.
746: From around USD 325 billion today, the combined market value of key energy transition minerals is set to increase by 55% in the APS by 2030 and by 80% in the NZE Scenario.

1631: Conducting structured risk assessments can assist policymakers in identifying vulnerabilities in the supply chain, devising appropriate security measures, and directing policy efforts to where they are most needed.
1632: We have performed “Clean energy transition risk assessments” for the six key energy transition minerals: copper, lithium, nickel, cobalt, graphite, and rare earth elements.
1633: These assessments are based on a comprehensive framework that combines both quantitative and qualitative analyses, to understand potential risk areas that could hamper progress towards energy transitions.
1634: The framework encompasses four main categories: supply risks, geopolitical risks, barriers to respond to disruptions, and exposure to environmental, social, and governance  and climate risks .
1635: The first category  assesses five dimensions.
1636: Pace of demand growth compares projected annual average demand growth rates in the Announced Pledges Scenario  between 2023 and 2030 in relation to historical growth rates between 2010 and 2019.
1637: Short term market balances assesses the near term balances between expected supply and primary supply requirements.
1638: Long term market balances in climate driven scenarios reviews the balances between expected supply and primary supply requirements in 2040 in the APS.
1639: Observed price volatility evaluates historical price volatility based on monthly prices between 2011 and 2023.
1640: Impact on clean energy cost examines the share of a material in the total cost of end use clean energy technologies to assess how price volatility could affect clean energy deployment.
1641: The second category  assesses five dimensions.
1642: Geographical concentration of mined supply assesses the expected share of the top three producing countries for mining in 2030 under the base case supply scenario.
1643: Geographical concentration of refined supply assesses the expected share of the top three producing countries for refining in 2030 under the base case supply scenario.
1644: N 1 supply and demand balances reviews market balances excluding the largest supplier by comparing the N 1 supply and material requirements in 2030 in the APS .
1645: Export risks of major suppliers assesses the risks of trade restriction measures by examining the weighted average export restriction risk score of the current production portfolio for both mining and refining, based on the Organisation for Economic Co operation and Development's  inventory of export restrictions on industrial raw materials and announced intentions.
1646: Hurdles to develop new projects in diversified regions conducts qualitative assessments of challenges in building supply chains in geographically diverse regions, such as lead time, capital requirements and technological barriers.
1647: The third category  assesses four dimensions.
1648: Visible stock levels reviews stock levels at major exchanges.
1649: While exchange stocks represent only a fraction of the industry's overall stock levels, they offer a valuable indication of an accessible buffer during disruptions.
1650: Transparency of pricing schemes conducts a qualitative assessment of market liquidity, transparency of pricing schemes and the availability of financial tools to hedge price risks.
1651: Availability of options to moderate demand assesses possible demand side and technology switching options to moderate demand growth in the event of supply tightness.
1652: Status of secondary supply assesses the ability of secondary supply to ramp up during market tightness by examining the share of secondary supply in total supply and its potential for growth.
1653: The fourth category  assesses five dimensions.
1654: Environmental performance of mining reviews the weighted average enviromental performance score of today's mined production, based on selected indicators in Yale’s Environmental Performance Index.
1655: Environmental performance of refining reviews the weighted average grid carbon intensity of the regions refining minerals today, considering that refining operations are highly electricity intensive.
1656: Social and governance performance assesses the weighted average corruption, human rights and conflict score of today's mined production, based on relevant indicators in the V Dem database.
1657: Exposure to water stress assesses the share of mine production located in areas with high and extreme high water stress and arid conditions.
1658: Exposure to earthquake risks assesses the share of mine production located in areas with high earthquake risks.

1757: The importance of unlocking the power of technology and recycling has long been a theme of IEA analysis and this was one of the key takeaways from the first ever IEA Critical Minerals and Clean Energy Summit in September 2023.
1758: Recycling creates a secondary supply of minerals that relieves the pressure on primary supply from mining and refining.
1759: A strong focus on recycling can deliver triple benefits: complementing primary mineral supplies, improving security of supply for regions with limited resource endowments and enhancing environmental performance and waste management.
1760: For base metals such as aluminium, recycling practices are well established, but this is not yet the case for many energy transition minerals such as lithium, nickel  and rare earth elements .

1811: Despite strong expected increases in demand, market transparency of commodities such as cobalt, lithium, and rare earth elements remains limited, challenging price hedging and discouraging investment and risk assessments.

1813: Transparency of pricing and market information brings important benefits to all aspects of the supply chain: producers and consumers are able to hedge their price risk, plan their stocks and production, and negotiate fair contracts.

1817: The primary element of a well functioning market for minerals and metals is transparency of pricing.

1854: The foremost reason to address the ESG risks within the mineral supply chain is to protect people, communities and the environment.
1855: Robust efforts to ensure that supply chains are responsible and sustainable will be necessary to ensure that energy transitions are people centred and that the benefits associated with mineral production, such as revenue and jobs, are captured in producer countries and communities.
1856: In parallel, improving the ESG performance of mineral supply chains can yield important security of supply benefits.
1857: In fact, without serious efforts to mitigate the ESG risks associated with mineral supply chains, there may not be sufficient supplies to support the rapid scale up of clean energy technologies that is needed to reach climate goals and to avert the worst effects of climate change.
1858: Governments and companies alike have a role in developing sustainable and responsible supply chains.
1859: While companies may champion sustainable and responsible practices and transparently monitor progress, governments play a crucial role in incentivising corporate action and creating a regulatory environment conducive to high ESG standards.
1860: While there are many ESG risks that can lead to supply disruptions, we have identified six priority areas that have particularly important implications for security of supply: water, GHG emissions, biodiversity, human rights, communities and corruption.
1861: Each of these risks impacts security of supply in a different way, but broadly, failures in these areas can limit market access, create legal barriers, discourage investment, damage reputation, increase the likelihood of opposition from local communities, and in some cases physically prevent projects from operating.

1863: Developing infrastructure that ensures secure water access for local communities can help companies prevent conflicts where water access is limited.
1864: Policy responses that encourage water stewardship include conditioning public investment to or establishing specific targets for water quality, use and effluents that improve over time.
1865: Companies that do not reduce and report GHG emissions face risks to market access and their reputation.
1866: Corporate reporting can build onto existing standards and external verification to provide transparent and credible data.
1867: Investment in on site renewables and energy efficiency can help drive decarbonisation efforts.
1868: Governments can improve or expand GHG reporting requirements and ensure that data on emissions are publicly available.
1869: Operations that fail to address biodiversity impacts may face regulatory barriers and reputational and investment risks , especially for mineral deposits located in key biodiversity areas.
1870: Companies can minimise land use and related impacts by working on project design and implementing technologies tailored to each site.
1871: Governments can strengthen biodiversity protections in mining regulations and permits and improve monitoring and disclosure of biodiversity data.
1872: Enhancing human rights standards in mining operations can mitigate operational disruptions and reduce divestment resulting from human rights violations, including child labour and forced labour.
1873: Corporations and governments can enable supply chain transparency by embedding human rights risks in due diligence systems or regulatory frameworks, while supporting the continued implementation and enforcement of protections.
1874: Meaningful engagement with local communities and Indigenous Peoples can help projects obtain and maintain a social licence to operate.
1875: This rests on credible local community and Indigenous Peoples led consultation schemes.
1876: Free, prior and informed consent of Indigenous Peoples and potentially impacted communities is a best practice, where not already required by law.
1877: Reducing corruption and governance risks can facilitate investment and strengthen public confidence in mining operations.
1878: This can be supported by targeted policies and the disclosure of permits, licences, and contracts company beneficial ownership and payments to governments.
1879: Considering the available levers for action, we have developed five key recommendations for policy makers to ensure that critical mineral value chains are sustainable and responsible Ensure legal and regulatory protections for the environment, workers, Indigenous Peoples and communities, backed by sufficient means of implementation and enforcement.
1880: Channel public spending to encourage the development of better practices and to incentivise good performance.
1881: Strengthen the collection and reporting of granular and standardised data to enable benchmarking and progress tracking throughout the supply chain.
1882: Improve transparency throughout the supply chain, including by enhancing traceability, undertaking due diligence and reporting publicly on risks and mitigation actions.
1883: Support the development of initiatives that help companies demonstrate that their operations are sustainable and responsible while ensuring cross compatibility and interoperability.
1884: Governments can play an important role in promoting improvements by incorporating the recommendations into their policy and investment decisions.

1923: A high risk occurs when new capacities require significantly higher capital and operating costs  and have a long lead time.
1924: A medium risk occurs when new capacities need to overcome moderate capital, lead time, and technological barriers.
1925: A low risk occurs when capital, lead time, and technological barriers are manageable.
1926: Visible stock levels are measured by stock visibility in major exchanges.
1927: A high risk is considered when stock visibility is limited.
1928: A medium risk occurs when monitoring stock levels is possible but volumes are lower than historical averages.
1929: A low risk occurs when there is ample visible stock in major exchanges.
1930: Transparency of pricing schemes is qualitatively assessed by examining market liquidity and transparency of pricing schemes.
1931: A high risk occurs when pricing is driven mainly by survey pricing and unregulated platforms with limited liquidity.
1932: A medium risk occurs when early stage regulated market trading is available but with limited liquidity.
1933: A low risk is present when there is established regulated market trading with ample liquidity.
1934: Availability of options to moderate demand is evaluated based on the availability of demand side options and technology switching options to manage demand growth in case of supply tightness.
1935: A high risk occurs when limited opportunities exist to reduce demand without sacrificing performance.
1936: A medium risk is present when there is scope for technology switching and behavioral changes to reduce demand, but it requires significant time and cost commitment.
1937: A low risk occurs when viable opportunities exist to reduce demand within a short period.
1938: Status of secondary supply is measured by the share of secondary supply in total supply and its potential for growth.
1939: A high risk occurs when the share of secondary supply remains low and shows no significant improvement.
1940: A medium risk occurs when the share of secondary supply remains low but is improving, or when the share is high but shows limited improvement.
1941: A low risk is present when the share of secondary supply remains high and continues to improve.
